title: How the IOPC report into 'Nick' inquiry failings falls well short of Sir Richard Henriques' findings
text:
Coming just days after Sir Richard Henriques' damning report into the actions of the police officers involved in Operation Midland, the findings of the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) will do little to convince people that the watchdog is fit for purpose.

While identifying "shortcomings and organisational failures", the 152 page report found no evidence of any misconduct by the five officers under investigation.

Those officers; Deputy Assistant Commissioner Steve Rodhouse; Detective Superintendent Kenny McDonald, Detective Sergeant Eric Sword, Detective Inspector Alison Hepworth and Detective Chief Inspector Diane Tudway, have been allowed to either retire or leave the Met for new roles – and none have faced sanction.

Sir Richard identified 43 separate police failings during the 16 month VIP paedophile probe, the IOPC found no evidence of deliberate wrongdoing.

Credibility of Nick

Sir Richard's report was damning of the Met's failure to test Beech's extraordinary claims that he had been raped and tortured for years by some of the country's most important public figures.

He was critical of the six month delay it took officers to interview Beech's mother Charmian, who told officers she had seen no evidence of abuse or injuries.

Detectives also failed to check with his schools, examine his medical records or seize his computers.
